apps.description:
Here’s the updated version of the developer documentation with a custom button feature that allows you to customize the button’s text and URL:

⸻

Developer Guide: Draft Collection JSON Format

Overview

The Draft Collection JSON format is used to store structured metadata about applications, developer tools, and documentation. This guide explains the format and how to add new entries correctly.

JSON Structure

Root Level Attributes

Key	Type	Description
title	string	The title of the collection.
description	string	A short description of the collection.
owner	string	The name of the collection owner.
email	string	Contact email of the owner.
repo	string	GitHub repository URL.
backgroundGradient	object	Defines UI gradient colors (from, to).
meta	object	Metadata about the repository (open-source, license, version, etc.).
apps	array	List of applications, tools, and documentation.

Background Gradient Format

"backgroundGradient": {  
  "from": "#121212",  
  "to": "#1E1E1E"  
}  

Item Structure

Each item inside apps follows this structure:

{  
  "id": 1,  
  "title": "App Name",  
  "type": "app",  
  "developer": "Developer Name",  
  "repo": "https://github.com/developer/repo",  
  "owner": "developer",  
  "gradientFrom": "#333333",  
  "gradientTo": "#111111",  
  "description": "Short description of the app.",  
  "price": "Free",  
  "category": "Category Name",  
  "releaseDate": "YYYY",  
  "hasDownloadButton": true,  
  "hasVisitSiteButton": true,  
  "downloadUrl": "https://example.com/download",  
  "customButton": {  
    "text": "Custom Button",  
    "url": "https://example.com/custom"  
  }  
}  

Required Fields
	•	id: Unique identifier.
	•	title: Name of the app/tool/documentation.
	•	type: Can be app, developer tool, runtime, OS, containerization, programming language, or docs.
	•	developer: Creator or developer of the entry.
	•	repo: GitHub repository link.
	•	owner: GitHub username or organization owning the repo.
	•	description: A brief summary.
	•	gradientFrom, gradientTo: UI gradient colors.

Optional Fields
	•	price: If applicable (e.g., Free, $9.99, Subscription).
	•	category: Defines the type of application (e.g., AI Tools, Developer Tools).
	•	releaseDate: Year of release.
	•	hasDownloadButton: true if download is available.
	•	hasVisitSiteButton: true if there’s an external website.
	•	downloadUrl: URL for downloading the app (if hasDownloadButton is true).
	•	customButton: Allows adding a customizable button with specific text and URL.

Custom Button Format:

The customButton field allows you to add a button with a custom label and URL. This button can be used to link to any external resource or action.

"customButton": {  
  "text": "Custom Button",  
  "url": "https://example.com/custom"  
}  

	•	text: The button label (e.g., “Learn More”, “Download Now”).
	•	url: The URL where the button will navigate when clicked.

Adding Documentation Entries

To add a documentation entry, use the following format:

{  
  "id": 10,  
  "title": "Getting Started",  
  "type": "docs",  
  "gradientFrom": "#444444",  
  "gradientTo": "#222222",  
  "description": "# Welcome to Draft Collection\n\nThis is a markdown-formatted guide explaining how to use the collection.",  
  "category": "Documentation"  
}  

	•	type: docs must be used for documentation.
	•	No buttons (hasDownloadButton, hasVisitSiteButton, customButton) should be present.
	•	Markdown is supported inside the description field. Remember, the description must be in Markdown format.

Example JSON with Multiple Entries

{  
  "title": "Draft Collection",  
  "description": "A curated list of apps and tools for developers.",  
  "owner": "Jaseunda",  
  "email": "hello@jaseunda.com",  
  "repo": "https://github.com/Jaseunda/draftsource",  
  "backgroundGradient": {  
    "from": "#121212",  
    "to": "#1E1E1E"  
  },  
  "apps": [  
    {  
      "id": 1,  
      "title": "VS Code",  
      "type": "app",  
      "developer": "Microsoft",  
      "repo": "https://github.com/microsoft/vscode",  
      "owner": "microsoft",  
      "gradientFrom": "#007ACC",  
      "gradientTo": "#0055AA",  
      "description": "Lightweight but powerful code editor.",  
      "price": "Free",  
      "category": "Developer Tools",  
      "releaseDate": "2016",  
      "hasDownloadButton": true,  
      "downloadUrl": "https://code.visualstudio.com/Download",  
      "customButton": {  
        "text": "Learn More",  
        "url": "https://code.visualstudio.com"  
      }  
    },  
    {  
      "id": 2,  
      "title": "Getting Started",  
      "type": "docs",  
      "gradientFrom": "#444444",  
      "gradientTo": "#222222",  
      "description": "# Welcome to Draft Collection\n\nThis is a markdown-formatted guide explaining how to use the collection.",  
      "category": "Documentation"  
    }  
  ]  
}  

How It Displays

The JSON data is rendered into a UI that visually categorizes applications and documentation. The display format typically follows these guidelines:
	1.	Gradient Backgrounds
	•	Each entry uses the gradientFrom and gradientTo colors for UI consistency.
	2.	App Listings
	•	Apps and Tools are displayed in cards with:
	•	Title
	•	Description
	•	Category
	•	Developer Name
	•	Buttons for Download and Visit Site (if applicable)
	•	Download URL is provided for the download button.
	•	Custom Button is displayed if specified in the entry.
	3.	Documentation Display
	•	Docs are shown as formatted markdown text within a dedicated section.
	•	No download or visit buttons are displayed.
	4.	Sorting & Filtering
	•	Items are grouped based on their category (e.g., AI Tools, Developer Tools, Docs).
	•	Users can filter or search for specific apps/docs.

Best Practices
	•	Always use unique IDs.
	•	Ensure type is correctly assigned.
	•	Use correct color gradients to maintain visual consistency.
	•	For documentation (docs type), ensure the description is properly formatted in Markdown.
	•	Custom Buttons can be used to link to any additional resources.

Final Notes

This format ensures consistency across all applications, tools, and documentation entries. If contributing, always validate your JSON before submission.
